page.title: 06RIVER DORE AND DULAS BROOK
page.content: The{ River Dore}gets its name from "dwr", the{Welsh}word for water. When the{Normans}came they thought the locals were saying " d'or" meaning golden so it became Dore and the area is now called the{Golden Valley.}It flows through{Abbey Dore}to{Pontrilas where it joins the{River Monnow.}It provides water for the sheep and cattle grazing along its banks and sometimes floods, making the land rich. Some of the trees along the banks are being cleared to make the river faster and deeper.{Dulas Brook runs from{Dulas}through{Ewyas Harold to{Pontrilas}where it joins the{Dore and the{Monnow.}It is usually not deep enough to row a boat down but there are pools deep enough to swim in. After heavy rain it quickly rises and becomes deep and fast enough to knock a child off its feet.
